hero.title: AISEA
hero.description: Be part of Southeast Asia's largest grassroots builder movement.

whatIsAISEA.title: What is AI.SEA
whatIsAISEA.paragraph1: AI.SEA is a builder network for people actually shipping AI in Southeast Asia.
whatIsAISEA.paragraph2: It's a coalition of local communities, operators, and engineers focused on one thing: building and deploying real AI systems under real constraints.
whatIsAISEA.paragraph3: We bring together builders from across SEA to co-build, test ideas in the open, and learn by doing. That includes hackathons, co-build sessions, sprints, and collaborations with serious tools and teams.
whatIsAISEA.paragraph4: AI.SEA exists because we need shared infrastructure, tighter feedback loops, and a way for capable builders to find each other and move faster, together.

slide1.title: Shared infrastructure
slide1.description: We pool resources so communities don't have to start from zero:

slide2.title: Cross-border collaboration
slide2.description: AI doesn't stop at borders — neither should builders.

slide3.title: Narrative & visibility
slide3.description: We help local builders be seen globally:
features: A shared SEA builder story that compounds over time

howItWorks.title: How it works
howItWorks.intro: AI.SEA is made up of local builder groups across Southeast Asia. Sessions are run on the ground by people who build, not event managers. While local communities run sessions, AI.SEA connects them regionally.

card1.title: Shared Formats
card1.description: Hackathons, co-build sessions, sprints, and challenges follow common formats. This keeps the bar clear and lets builders move between cities and communities without friction.

card2.title: Build in public
card2.description: Projects and progress is shared across communities. Ideas can be tested without judgement, feedback can be obtained, and partners can be found across multiple countries.

card3.title: Serious Tools & Partners
card3.description: Builders get access to real tooling, credits, and support from teams actually shipping AI.

globalNetwork.title: Our global network
globalNetwork.subheading: Join 10,000+ builders already active across the world.

startChapter.title: Start a chapter in your city today
startChapter.description: Join the AI.SEA network and bring the builder movement to your city.

manifesto.title: The AISEA Manifesto
manifesto.subtitle: On building institutions, not just communities

intro.paragraph1: Southeast Asia does not lack talent. It does not lack ambition.
intro.paragraph3: Across the region, AI communities are built with care and effort. People organize meetups, run hackathons, mentor builders, and try to hold things together. For a while, it works.
intro.paragraph5: Then a lead burns out, moves on, or steps back. The community weakens. Relationships fade. Past work is lost. The next person starts again from zero.
intro.paragraph6: This is not a people problem. It is a structure problem.
intro.paragraph7: AISEA exists to address that failure.

independence.title: Independence is not enough
independence.paragraph1: Most communities operate independently. This independence matters. It allows communities to reflect local needs, culture, and energy. But independence also has limits.
independence.paragraph2: On their own, communities have little leverage with sponsors, platforms, or partners. Support is short-term. Commitments are shallow. Value flows out faster than it flows back in.
independence.paragraph3: Over time, community builders put in more than they get out. Not because others intend harm, but because the system makes it easy to take and hard to give back.
independence.paragraph4: AISEA exists to make independence sustainable.

whatAISEA.title: What AISEA is trying to build
whatAISEA.paragraph1: AISEA exists so AI communities in Southeast Asia don't have to operate alone.
whatAISEA.paragraph2: It does not replace local communities. It does not dictate culture or programming.
whatAISEA.paragraph3: Instead, AISEA does the work communities cannot easily do alone:
list: long-term relationships with partners and funders
whatAISEA.paragraph4: Communities stay local, but infrastructure is shared.

authority.title: On authority and coordination
authority.paragraph1: Real coordination needs authority. Without it, alliances stay informal and fragile.
authority.paragraph2: AISEA operates with a central structure and delegated country teams. This allows negotiations, funding, and partnerships to happen once, rather than being repeated by every community.

autonomy.title: On autonomy and choice
autonomy.paragraph1: AISEA does not prohibit communities from operating independently.
autonomy.paragraph2: Communities can and will continue to:
list: run programs that make sense for their context
autonomy.paragraph3: AISEA is built on trade-offs. Communities choose whether to participate because:
autonomy.paragraph4: If AISEA does not offer real value, it does not deserve participation.

valueFlow.title: On value flow
valueFlow.paragraph1: Many ecosystems fail because value flows in one direction.
valueFlow.paragraph2: Communities are often asked to host speakers, promote platforms, or run events in exchange for exposure or vague future promises. The work is done by community operators. The long-term benefit goes elsewhere.
valueFlow.paragraph3: AISEA exists to change this. Access to communities should lead to real returns:
list: funding that supports operators, not just one-off events
partnerships that last beyond a single activation
valueFlow.paragraph4: If value keeps flowing out without being reinvested, the system is not working. AISEA exists to make sure communities benefit from the value they help create.

crossBorder.title: On Cross-Border Collaboration
crossBorder.paragraph1: Cross-border collaboration in Southeast Asia is harder than it should be.
crossBorder.paragraph2: Talent is spread across the region, but access is not. Most collaboration today is limited to talks, one-off events, or personal introductions that fade quickly.
crossBorder.paragraph3: This is not a lack of interest. It is a lack of structure. AISEA exists to make cross-border work the norm.
crossBorder.paragraph4: By sharing standards, context, and coordination, AISEA allows communities and builders to work across countries without starting from scratch each time.
crossBorder.paragraph5: This includes joint programs, shared reviews, cross-border teams, and regional showcases. The goal is simple: work done in one place should travel further than it currently does.

continuity.title: On continuity and succession
continuity.paragraph2: AISEA exists to make this more likely by encouraging:
list: shared leadership rather than single points of failure
smoother transitions when operators step back
continuity.paragraph3: Continuity is a requirement for any ecosystem that hopes to compound over time.

accountability.title: On accountability
accountability.paragraph1: AISEA exists to act on behalf of communities, not above them. Its role is to coordinate, negotiate, and maintain shared systems. It is not meant to operate without checks.
accountability.paragraph2: Country-level AISEA teams are trusted with real responsibility. They are expected to act in the interest of the communities they represent, not for personal gain or attention. Their job is to bring support in and make sure value flows back.
accountability.paragraph3: Accountability runs both ways. Communities that take part are expected to contribute and follow shared norms. In return, AISEA is expected to use its position carefully, openly, and for the benefit of the wider ecosystem.
accountability.paragraph4: If something stops working, it should be addressed. Roles can be reviewed. Operators can change. Decisions can be questioned. Authority that cannot be challenged does not last.
accountability.paragraph5: The system matters more than any individual.

contribution.title: On community contribution
contribution.paragraph1: AISEA is not a passive network.
contribution.paragraph2: Communities that take part are expected to contribute to the shared system. What that contribution looks like may differ, but it must be real.
contribution.paragraph3: Some communities contribute time and effort by helping run programs, reviewing work, or supporting cross-border efforts. Others contribute by putting forward serious builders and sharing what they learn. In some cases, communities contribute resources that help sustain the system itself.
contribution.paragraph4: There is no single required form. But there is a shared expectation: participation involves giving, not just receiving.
contribution.paragraph5: AISEA does not measure communities by size or reach. A small community that shows up consistently is more valuable than a large one that does not.

commitment.title: A long-term commitment
commitment.paragraph1: AISEA is designed to ensure that:
list: communities do not collapse when individuals leave
operators are supported rather than exhausted
the ecosystem compounds instead of resetting, and
the region comes together as a whole
commitment.paragraph2: If AISEA succeeds, it will not feel revolutionary. It will feel stable.
commitment.paragraph3: And stability, in a region that constantly has to start over, is already a meaningful form of progress.

hero.title: Reach 10,000+ active AI builders across APAC
hero.subheading: Stop paying for low-signal leads. Get direct access to builders who actually ship and give real feedback.

navigation.title: Work with AI.SEA
navigation.caseStudiesHint: Swipe or use arrows to explore

traditionalGTM.title: Traditional GTM doesn't scale the way you need it to
traditionalGTM.point1: Paid ads are expensive and noisy.
traditionalGTM.point2: Cold outreach rarely reaches real builders.
traditionalGTM.point3: DevRel takes months to show signal and is hard to measure.
traditionalGTM.conclusion: Most teams only realize something is wrong after the roadmap is locked and budget is gone.

aiseaHelps.text1: AI.SEA helps AI companies reach qualified technical users in Southeast Asia without burning budget on ads, cold outbound, or slow DevRel programs.
aiseaHelps.text2: We work with teams who need real usage, fast feedback, and regional traction.

whatAISEA.title: What AI.SEA gives you

card1.title: Direct Builder Access
card1.description: Reach active AI builders across Southeast Asia who are already shipping projects, not passive audiences or mailing lists.

card2.title: Trusted Distribution
card2.description: Your product is introduced through established local communities, not ads, cold outreach, or generic newsletters. This ensures direct, targeted outreach to the best category of builders for your product.

card3.title: In-Context Visibility
card3.description: Your product shows up inside hackathons, sprints, and co-build sessions where tools are chosen under real constraints.

whatAISEA.footer: Learn what works before you commit roadmap, headcount, or regional GTM spend.

bounties.title: Bounties
bounties.description: Well-scoped problems with clear acceptance criteria. We help define the problem, set reward tiers, distribute it to the right builders, and handle submissions and evaluation.
bounties.bestFor: Best for: rapid experimentation, targeted tasks, early technical validation.

challenges.title: Challenges & Activations
challenges.description: Time-boxed build sprints (from 48 hours to a few weeks) focused on a theme, product, or problem space. We handle builder recruitment, onboarding, tooling enablement, and demo coordination. Partners provide the problem framing, success criteria, and optional mentorship.
challenges.bestFor: Best for: idea generation, early adoption, ecosystem activation, surfacing talent.

pilots.title: Pilot Builds
pilots.description: Curated builder pods working on a real problem under realistic constraints. Unlike challenges, pilots are narrower and execution-focused. We form small teams, define success metrics upfront, and aim for production-minded prototypes that could realistically be deployed or extended internally. Each pilot ends with a technical handover and evaluation.
pilots.bestFor: Best for: testing real use cases, validating ROI, de-risking larger builds.

infrastructure.title: Infrastructure & Enablement
infrastructure.description: Support that helps builders succeed with your tools across the ecosystem. This includes tool credits, API access, datasets, documentation, and hands-on workshops run with AI.SEA chapters. The goal: get builders to ship with your stack and continue using it beyond a single event.
infrastructure.bestFor: Best for: sustained adoption, ecosystem pull-through, long-term usage.

lovable.title: Lovable Hackathon reached 200+ non-coders
lovable.paragraph1: AI.SEA partnered with Lovable to run a targeted hackathon designed to reach builders outside their usual technical audience.
lovable.paragraph2: Instead of engineers, the event attracted 200+ non-coders, including 40–50+ year old business owners, operators, and solo founders. Many participants were already running real businesses and were actively looking for tools to ship faster without engineering teams.
lovable.paragraph3: During the hackathon, Lovable became the primary tool participants used to build landing pages, prototypes, and internal tools for their existing businesses. This was not experimentation for fun. It was applied usage under real commercial constraints.
lovable.result: Strong product lock-in. Participants continued using Lovable beyond the event because it directly replaced slower, more expensive workflows they were already paying for.

cursorAnthropic.title: Cursor and Anthropic onboarded ~700 senior builders in SEA in one day
cursorAnthropic.paragraph1: AI.SEA partnered with Cursor, Anthropic, and ecosystem partners to run one of Malaysia's largest AI hackathons.
cursorAnthropic.paragraph2: The event drew over 2,000 signups, with approximately 1,000 builders attending in person within a single day. Around 70% of participants were senior developers, founders, or technical leads, closely matching the ideal user profile for both Cursor and Anthropic.
cursorAnthropic.paragraph3: Participants actively used Cursor and Anthropic tools throughout the hackathon to build and ship working projects under time pressure. This created immediate hands-on onboarding, not passive exposure.
cursorAnthropic.paragraph4: The top 15 teams received recognition from local VCs and ecosystem partners including AWS.
cursorAnthropic.result: Public demonstration of how Cursor and Anthropic accelerated development speed, improved iteration quality, and enabled teams to ship more ambitious products within tight timelines.

elevenlabs.title: ElevenLabs demonstrated a new product feature through 150+ builders in 2 hours
elevenlabs.paragraph1: AI.SEA partnered with ElevenLabs to run a focused 2-hour hackathon designed to showcase a new feature of its voice AI platform.
elevenlabs.paragraph2: 150+ builders participated in a single, tightly scoped challenge: re-dub an existing short video using ElevenLabs. The constraint forced every participant to touch the feature directly, not just watch a demo.
elevenlabs.paragraph3: The competition format encouraged memes and humor, lowering the barrier to participation while still requiring real product usage. Participants were required to publicly demo their outputs on YouTube, creating organic distribution beyond the event itself.
elevenlabs.result: Within two hours, ElevenLabs achieved hands-on adoption, clear qualitative feedback, and broad public visibility for the new feature without running a traditional launch campaign.

toolPlatform.title: If you are a tool or platform.
toolPlatform.description: We design and run builder-facing programs such as hackathon tracks, sprints, co-build sessions, and pilots. This gives you real usage, technical feedback, and early adopters, not just impressions.

companyOperator.title: If you are a company or operator.
companyOperator.description: We help you explore, test, and deploy AI in realistic environments. This can take the form of scoped build sprints, problem-driven challenges, or embedded collaborations with experienced builders across the region.

fundEcosystem.title: If you are a fund or ecosystem partner.
fundEcosystem.description: We surface high-signal builders, teams, and projects through our activities. This includes deal flow, founder visibility, and early access to experiments before they become obvious.

howWeWork.title: How we work.
howWeWork.description: Engagements are designed to be practical and time-bound. We start with a clear objective, design a format that fits, and execute with local communities across SEA. Most work is run as a sprint or program, not an open-ended engagement.

getInTouch.title: Get in touch.
getInTouch.description: If you want to run a track, pilot a product, sponsor a program, or explore a longer-term partnership, reach out and we will scope something concrete.

items.question: What makes AI.SEA different?
answer: AI.SEA combines regional reach with precise matching.

We operate a hub-and-spoke network of local builder communities across Southeast Asia. That gives partners access to a wide pool of builders, while still allowing us to surface the right people for specific tools, problems, or use cases.
Most communities offer either scale or depth. We're built to do both.

items.question: Who do you work with?
answer: We work with teams building serious AI products: developer tools, platforms, infrastructure, startups, and funds that care about real usage, feedback, and long-term adoption.
If you're looking for logo exposure or passive sponsorships, we're not a fit.

items.question: What does "working with AI.SEA" actually involve?
answer: It means collaborating on build-driven initiatives. This can include hackathon tracks, co-build sessions, sprints, pilot programs, or regionally coordinated activations — all designed around real usage and execution.

items.question: How do you ensure quality, not just volume?
answer: Distribution happens at the community level. Selection happens at the builder level.
We don't broadcast everything to everyone. We route opportunities through local leads and formats that surface builders with the right skills, intent, and readiness to ship.

items.question: What do partners get out of this?
answer: Access to high-signal builders across SEA, real product usage in live builds, direct practitioner feedback, and the ability to activate multiple markets through a single coordinated surface.

items.question: Can we run something locally or regionally?
answer: You can activate a single city or community, or run a coordinated effort across multiple countries using shared formats and infrastructure.

items.question: How do we get started?
answer: Reach out with what you're building, who you want to reach, and what success looks like for you.
If there's a clear fit, we'll design something concrete and execution-focused together.

hero.title: AI.SEA Residency
hero.subheading: The home for the world's most ambitious builders

threeMonths.title: Three months to do your best work.
threeMonths.paragraph1: The AI.SEA Residency is a short, selective program for exceptional builders in Southeast Asia.
threeMonths.paragraph2: Its purpose is simple: bring high-signal talent together, remove friction, give them serious tools and context, then get out of the way.
threeMonths.paragraph3: This is not an accelerator. There are no pitches, no demo days, and no forced problem statements.
threeMonths.paragraph4: Builders work on what they believe should exist. AI.SEA provides access, environment, and pressure. What comes out goes back into the ecosystem.

whoItsFor.title: Who the AI.SEA Residency Is For
whoItsFor.intro: The AI.SEA Residency is for builders who already ship. People who don't need motivation, structure, or permission. The builders who want to change the world and want to be surrounded by others who want to do the same.
bullets: you've built and shipped real things, even if they failed
you care more about doing the work than talking about it
you're constrained by environment, not ambition
you're ready to spend a short period building at full capacity, with no distractions
whoItsFor.lookingFor: We aren't looking for fancy credentials, huge followings, or years of experience. We are looking for **momentum**, **ambition**, and the **drive** to do the impossible.

whoItsNotFor.title: Who It's Not For
bullets: you want a curriculum, a mentor, or a roadmap
you're chasing pitch opportunities or prizes
you're optimizing for visibility and virality over progress
whoItsNotFor.conclusion: There are no demos to impress. Only outcomes and progress matter.

step1.title: Apply
step1.description: Submit an application showing real work. We're looking for evidence of how you build.

step2.title: Signal Review
step2.description: Applications are reviewed for depth, trajectory, and fit with the residency environment.

step3.title: Short Follow-Up (If Needed)
step3.description: Some applicants may be asked for a short follow-up or conversation. This is not an interview, it's a fit check.

step4.title: Invitation
step4.description: A small group is invited to join each residency. Seats are limited by design.

step5.title: Commit
step5.description: If invited, you're expected to fully commit for the duration of the residency.

apply.title: Ready to change your trajectory?
apply.button: Apply to join the Residency now
